LOUIS DOBBS, FOX NEWS HOST: Always good to talk with you. Thanks so much. Michael Pillsbury, Tom Fitton and John Solomon are with us tomorrow. I hope you will as well. Thanks for joining us tonight. Good night from Sussex.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX NEWS ANCHOR: Good morning happy Tuesday everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, June 23rd your top stories right now it is 6:00 am on the east coast.

The origins of the Russia probe Attorney General William Barr goes after Congressman Adam Schiff and fired FBI agent Peter Strzok as evidence piles up over what really jump started the investigation.

Markets are higher this morning Futures back in the green after plunging more than 400 points overnight this after White House Peter Navarro Futures say that the China Trade Deal was over but President Trump and Navarro quickly confirming phase 1 is still on.

Markets finishing up yesterday even as cases of Coronavirus spike in several states, the NASDAQ seeing its 20th record close in 2020, a big day yesterday. Autonomous chaos meanwhile Seattle is now looking to dismantle the Capitol Hill occupied protest as a new one pops off in Washington D.C.

Plus, back to the ball game Major League Baseball looks to a shorter season this year but the players still need to get on board. For more on the sports talk stay with us next hour tennis pro Andy Roddick is here.

Joining me live to talk about the future of the U. S. Open and his new Bourbon venture plus America to get together during the pandemic. We will talk with one CEO who kept all its employees on the payroll even bringing new ones on "Mornings With Maria" is live right now.

And European markets this morning seeing an up tick tock EU officials warning that China during Monday's virtual summit they could possibly cut ties if there's no sign of opening up the economy to European countries.

As you see the FTSE 100 is up 65, the CAC Quarante in Paris is up 72 and the DAX Index in Germany high by 266. Overnight in Asia grade across the board Japan is signaling that it will keep it plans to gain a surplus by 2025 despite massive spending on a COVID-19 crisis the Japanese NIKKEI average overnight up half of 1 percent.

Now the top stories that we are watching this morning. Major unrests in our nation's capitalist as protesters attempt to create what they're calling a black house autonomous zone, right outside of the White House fencing in large garbage cans being used to build a barrier. The zone letters sheen spray painted on the columns of the historic Saint John's Church that same Church set on fire by protesters last month fights breaking out as the protesters clash with police.

Rioters met with police as they tried to take down the statue of Andrew Jackson in Lafayette Park President Trump promising that there will be consequences.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT, UNITED STATES OF AMERICA: Something very similar we're going to do an Executive Order and we're going to make the city's guard their monuments. This is a disgrace.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: The secret service says four members of the media were asked to leave the White House yesterday for their own safety amid the demonstrations on the White House grounds. The City of Seattle moving to end the police free Capitol Hill organized protesters CHOP zone after a man was shot and killed there over the weekend.

This zone was embraced by Mayor Jenny Durkan earlier this month. Durkan saying that it could bring on a "Summer of Love" now she's changing her tune saying that Seattle will try to scale the CHOP zone back and let police returned to the east precincts.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JENNY DURKAN, SEATTLE MAYOR: What we believe individuals, organizations and others can continue to gather on Capitol Hill peacefully. The continued disorder, the violence and the impacts on residents and businesses are not just at odds with the message of justice and equity. They cannot continue to occur.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Residents near the CHOP zone criticized the city for waiting until the deadly shooting to break up those protests. Meanwhile in New York City gun violence skyrockets across New York City and police warned that this could be the new normal.

The first 3 weeks of June seeing 125 shooting incidents 53 of which coming last week alone. It is reportedly been nearly 8 years since the city has recorded this many shootings in one week. The troubling trend coming on the heels of NYPD Commissioner Dermot Shea's decision to disband the city's anticrime plainclothes unit after number of complaints against its members.

President Trump signing an Executive Order meanwhile expanding current immigration restrictions on certain visas they include the H1B and H2B visas related to guest worker programs as well as some J&L visas related to education exchanges an executive transfers.

The Administration says this will safeguard jobs for unemployed Americans. The move has drawn criticism from technology companies like Twitter and one of the President's allies Senator Lindsey Graham tweeting this unfortunately I fear the President's decision today to temporarily shut down these programs will create a drag on our economic recovery.

The restrictions which take place effective tomorrow will not apply to visa holders already in the United States. Today President Trump is headed to Arizona to mark the 200th mile of the border wall. The President will reportedly be briefed on construction of that wall then we'll meet with the local leaders on border security.

After visiting Hume the President will head to Phoenix where he will speak to the students for Trump Convention. We'll cover that all day this morning. Dr. Anthony Fauci on Capitol Hill today meanwhile to testify on the U. S. response to COVID-19 pandemic as the number of cases rises in about half of the country right now.

Fauci along with other top health officials will answer questions from a House Committee about testing and treatments for the Coronavirus. The hearing comes as more states reporting higher number of COVID-19 cases among young people in the south and in the west.

Health officials say that they're seeing a radical shift as adults in their twenties and thirties contract the deadly virus now. Texas - a record jump in the number of new cases in part to people gathering at bars and beaches.

Markets this morning are higher Futures indicating a gain at the start of trading this morning after a volatile overnight session. Investors seeing DOW Futures trading down as many as 439 points overnight following White House Trade Adviser Peter Navarro's comments on the U. S. China Trade Deal last night on Fox News watch this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: There had been progress made on that trade deal but given everything that's happened in all the things you just listed is that over?

PETER NAVARRO, WHITE HOUSE TRADE ADVISER: It's over yes. They came here on January 15th to sign that trade deal--

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Yes.

NAVARRO: --and that was a full 2 months after they knew the virus was out and about it was at the time when they're already sent hundreds of thousands of people to this country to spread that virus. And it was just minutes after wheels up when that plane took off that we began to hear about this pandemic.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Markets rebounding quickly after Navarro walked back those comments saying this comments have been taken wildly out of context. They had nothing at all to do with the phase one trade deal which continues in place. I was simply speaking to the lack of trust we now have of the Chinese Communist Party after they lied about the origins of China virus and foisted a pandemic upon the world.

With that markets came back President Trump also waited on Twitter he wrote this the China trade deal is fully intact. Hopefully they will continue to live up to the terms of the agreement and of course those terms are $200 billion worth of purchases of agricultural and commodities.

Joining the conversation this morning Haverford Trust Company Co-Chief Investment Officer Hank Smith also joining me this morning is Fox Business Dagen McDowell the Wall Street Journal Senior Writer John Hilsenrath and Senior Fellow at The National Taxpayers Union and Forward Strategies President Mattie Duppler great to see everybody this morning.

Thanks so much for being here. And Hank I want to kick it off with you. So now Peter Navarro and the President walking back those comments that the deal is not over but let's face it. The Chinese Communist Party has not kept up in terms of the promises were still waiting for that $250 billion of purchases. We may not get it in the face of all of this and the relationship has changed. How does that impact markets?

HANK SMITH, HAVERFORD TRUST COMPANY CO-CIO: Well, it clearly shows you that trade are still important issue. I mean what the S&P Futures were down 400 points as you pointed out. But also the market knows that China's dealing with their own economic problems right now as are all countries do to this pandemic.

But trade and if we get into a trade war is clearly a headwind for the economy as we learned a year before. And hopefully we don't have to learn that lesson again. But you are right in pointing out our relationship with China is afraid to say the least.

BARTIROMO: So I mean, why was this such a surprise initially that market sold off when Navarro said it's over? They still haven't bought the phase one promises anyway.

SMITH: Well, that is true. But again I think the market is over - is overlooking the fact that they have involved due to the fact that we're in this pandemic. And we - you know we have to - we have to heal our country of the pandemic and then the expectation is that they will be of good all at least at phase one.

BARTIROMO: Yes, Dagen jump in here. The NASDAQ hitting its 20th record close of 2020 yesterday get big tech companies like Apple, Amazon and Microsoft powering the NASDAQ forward?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS: Yes. On that note Hank, "The Wall Street Journal" wrote about this yesterday that the games are more widespread and are driven just necessarily by these tech monopolies if you well is that a positive sign in terms of the breadth of this rally?

SMITH: No question that it is a broadening out of the market and both offense and defense is participating. You know defense those companies that are hold up very well in a declining economic environment and then offense the more cyclical companies.

And then you have tech which is both offense and defense which is a remarkable transition from say 20 years ago. But I think it's a very healthy sign that the market is broadening out and it portends I think well for future gains.

BARTIROMO: John Hilsenrath, what are your thoughts on what's taken place with China? Obviously overnight markets were back and forth 400 point selloff when we first heard Peter Navarro says that, that the deal is over.

JON HILSENRATH, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL SENIOR WRITER: Well, you know I think we're in a new economic Cold War with China and this is an example of it. And you know we're also going to see it on immigration issues in Chinese students coming to America to study.

And this is something I wanted to ask Hank about. The Trump Administration announced that it would start scaling back H1B visas. Hank, I want to hear your thought about what does that mean for the economy and for growth?

As an investor I'm sure you're thinking about growth a lot of these tech companies look to H1B visas what's your read on this decision to cut back on visas into the country?

SMITH: Yes so John, look of the Trump Administration in terms of growth has gotten it right on taxes. It has gotten it right on a regulation and deregulation. But they've got it wrong on trade and they've gotten it wrong on immigration.

This country needs immigration. We need immigration both with PHDs and we need immigration with blue collared labors. And also our schools and colleges and universities are desperate for foreign students in large part because 95 percent of them plus or minus a full K.

And so it is a big question this fall as to whether foreign student's in particular Asian students will be able to attend our colleges and universities. And that's going to have a huge financial impact.

BARTIROMO: Hank, is it just about the money then? I mean at the end of the day we've spoken with many Senators who have said that this is a national security issue. The Chinese Communist Party sends in researchers to steal our data and they're doing it right now.

I mean that was one of the key things I think that Senator Cotton was talking about when said we need to be restricting these visas. And I suspect this is part of what the President's plan is here that I mean there's a reason that at least 7 university professors are workers at universities have been indicted for getting money from the Chinese Communist Party for sending back data. So when does it become a national security issue and not just about the money?

SMITH: Right. But also Maria and you have a very good point. But also a lot of these foreign students stay in the United States and become very, very productive. Create companies and really add to Silicon Valley. So you know they're always going to be issues and problems.

But I think net, net immigration is a plus for this country in terms of growth as opposed to a drain on our resources.

BARTIROMO: All right. We'll leave it there. Hank Smith so it's a pleasure to see sir. Thanks so much.

SMITH: Good to be with you.

BARTIROMO: Hank Smith joining us from Haverford. We're just getting started this morning coming up infectious disease expert Dr. Amesh Adalja is here on the Coronavirus surge in Florida, Texas and other states. Are we seeing the beginnings of a second wave?

Former California Congressman Darrell Issa is here on California's move to expand voting by mail and what Attorney General William Barr told me about the issue? And then in the 7:00 am hour we'll have California Congressman John Garamendi and Florida Congressman Michael Waltz on the 2020 race and the COVID-19 pandemic in their states.

Plus, AFL-CIO President Richard Trumka is here on Facebook's move to allow employers to block the word union eyes on workplace platforms. And tennis pro Andy Roddick got his new Bourbon business we're are to hear that.

Plus the 8:00 am hour we have Ohio Senator Rob Portman on the government's plan to take on China and Archbishop of New York Cardinal Timothy Dolan on the challenges Catholic schools have been facing during this pandemic. Don't miss a moment of it we've got a big three hours. Quick break and we'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Coronavirus cases are on the rise as states reopen at least 20 states seeing an increase in infections now. In Florida cases are now topping 100,000 in Georgia and in Houston hospitalizations are rising dramatically and in Arizona one in 5 people have now tested positive.

Joining us right now is Infectious Disease Expert Senior Scholar at the Johns Hopkins Center for Health Security Dr. Amesh Adalja. Dr. Adalja great to see you, what's behind this jump in new cases in your view is it due to more testing or the reopenings?

DR. AMESH ADALJA, INFECTIOUS DISEASE EXPERT: --things we do know that states are doing more testing but if you look at the percentage positivity of tests, that's going up faster than the number of tests are going up.

So there is spread that's going on in communities that's not really being recognized and that's the important thing is trying to get the case contact investigation scaled up to be able to stop that. Those cases are spilling into the hospital so we do have an issue in some states that many of us are concerned about.

BARTIROMO: Are more PR - are more young people testing positive now? I mean are there fears that they could pass it to the elderly given the numbers we're seeing on young people?

DR. ADALJA: That's definitely the case. We're seeing a skewing where the average age of diagnosed cases is going down and that's because today we do have more tests. So we're testing more mild cases where the younger people tend to cluster and be social out distancing restrictions are lifted.

The first people that are about to reengage in society tend to be younger and they're getting infected at bars and restaurants. And I think that's a challenge because maybe they won't get sick but they might be a bridge to somebody that could be vulnerable that could end up being hospitalization.

So we really have to clamp down on those cases by actually identifying them and isolating them and doing contact tracing. So we have to get very aggressive with the case management of this new case we're getting in certain states.

BARTIROMO: Sure, really troubling info. Dr. Amesh Adalja good to see you this morning sir, thank you very much.

DR. ADALJA: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: We'll keep watching that of course. We'll take a break when we come back at the clue that almost took down a President what Attorney General William Barr is saying about the report? Muller investigation as well that's coming up stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back Attorney General Bill Barr confirming to me that the FBI claimed it was a conversation in a wine bar that sparked the probe into Russia collusion. During my sit down, exclusive sit down with the AG this week I spoke to him about the origins of the Russia investigation and the beginnings of the alleged coup to take down President Trump.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: But is there any evidence that in fact it was appropriate to launch an investigation other than a conversation in a bar? I know that George Papadopoulos had a conversation in a bar.

WILLIAM BARR, U.S. ATTORNEY GENERAL: That is the official version of what happened at that comment in a London wine bar was with the basis really watch for going forward. And I've said that I thought that was a very slender reed to get law enforcement and intelligence agencies involved in investigating the campaign of one's political opponent.

BARTIROMO: Can you tell me at all just mischievous?

BARR: No, but I'll just say that one of the things it takes time is that Mr. Durham is trying to look at all the various allegations and concerns that have been raised. So he has been looking at things pre July and trying to run those down.

And so there's a lot to look at. Throughout this whole episode both before and after the election and he's diligently looking at everything.

BARTIROMO: When did the DOJ start paying informants?

BARR: I don't know, but it's common practice.

BARTIROMO: Okay.

B ARR: A confidential human sources.

BARTIROMO: Well, I guess because you've been around. I mean you were the AG under George H. W. Bush and you've seen a lot of the same player so Alexander Downer, Mifsud are these regular names that have been working with the intelligence community before?

BARR: I couldn't I couldn't say anything about that.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: And he couldn't say anything about that because this is an active criminal investigation taking place right now. So Dagen McDowell now that we know that the FBI is claiming that's the reason that they investigated Donald Trump because of this conversation in a wine bar. Next question becomes was that conversation organic or was that information planted?

Joseph Mifsud met George Papadopoulos in April of 2016 and told him Russia has Hillary Clinton's email that's what George Papadopoulos said to his informant friend several months later in a wine bar Dagen?

MCDOWELL: And the issue is now the clock is ticking on the John Durham investigation with the Presidential Election coming up in a matter of months. And I'll tie it to the firing of the U. S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York Geoffrey Berman for him being told to get the heck out it.

The Wall Street Journal Editorial page touches on this. That this messy removal of Geoffrey Berman it - Bill Barr loses some political capital here, wasted and it's in the interest of people in the FBI and the Justice Department who push this to launch the investigation into President Trump sold along with some members of the media who sold the phony Steele dossier to the American people and the whole Russia collusion story.

It's in their interest to focus on Geoffrey Berman's removal because it absolves them of any responsibility of investigating a Presidential Candidate and a President and then selling a lot of the American people. So it's exceedingly complicated right now.

BARTIROMO: Well, it's really extraordinary to me that more people are not outraged by what has taken place in 2016? Jon Hilsenrath we've spoken about this. You would think that people would not want to see the powers that these people in powerful positions put their finger on the scale but that is exactly what took place in 2016 and we will learn more about the activity before July 2016 that's when the FBI said the start of the investigation but we know there was a lot of activity informants as early as March and April of 16 that same year?

HILSENRATH: Well, and Maria I think you're right. And I think Dagen put her finger on it. You know we talk about the fog of war. I think for the next 4 or 5 months we're going to be seeing the fog of political war fair where both sides are throwing out all kinds of accusations and versions of events of what happened in 2016?

But also what's going on right now we know there's all this fighting about mail in ballots. I think for you know most Americans watching it it's going to be hard, very hard to make sense of it all.

BARTIROMO: We're going to talk about the mail and ballots coming up. Also coming up Americans headed to the ballot box that debate the potential risks over mail in voting ballots and what the Attorney General told me about that? Stay with us for we're going to talk about that. Then dinosaurs dominate again Jurassic Park another classic blockbusters making noise about and big bucks at the Box Office. We're going to take a look. Stay with us.

MARIA BARTIROMO, FOX BUSINESS HOST, MORNINGS WITH MARIA: Welcome back. Good Tuesday morning everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Tuesday, June 23rd.

Let's take a look at where the markets are right now, 6:31 a.m. on the East coast. Futures are back in green this morning after plunging better than 400 points overnight. This, as Trade and Manufacturing Policy Director Peter Navarro appeared to say the China trade deal was over in an interview with Martha MacCallum last night. President Trump and Navarra quickly confirmed phase one was still on, after markets reacted immediately. In the end, markets finished up yesterday, even as the cases of coronavirus spike in several states. The NASDAQ seeing its 20th record close in 2020, as you see yesterday the Dow Industrials were up 153, and this morning futures show a gain of almost 300 points.

European markets, meanwhile, also seeing uptick this morning. EU officials are warning China during Monday's virtual summit, it could possibly cut ties if there is no sign of opening up the Chinese economy to European countries. All the major indices overseas higher in Europe. The DAX Index in Germany up 2 1/2 percent right now.

In Asia, meanwhile, green across the board there as well. Japan signaling it will keep to its plans to gaining surplus by 2025 despite massive spending on the COVID-19 crisis. The Nikkei Average up 1/2 of one percent.

Meanwhile, the European Union taking a harder line on trade with China, Cheryl Casone now with more details on that story. Cheryl.

CHERYL CASONE, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: That is right Maria. Good morning, some strong words from top European officials to China. They are warning Beijing to honor its promise to open its economy or risk damage to the relationship between the two groups. The EU wants greater access to China's market, particularly in the auto, telecommunications, and biotech sectors as the block looks to rebalance trade and investment ties with that country. Trade volumes reach $1.67 billion at daily, and EU officials say this is an unbalanced trade and investment relationship. The virtual summit, by the way, was held as the EU is accusing China of spreading disinformation about how Europe handled the COVID-19 crisis, and also, they have issues with China's grip on Hong Kong.

Well, an incredible show of support for Nascar driver Bubba Wallace after a noose was discovered in the Alabama racetrack driver's garage. Drivers, pit crews and others escorted Wallace's number 43 car onto the track at Talladega Super Speedway yesterday, just one day after that incident. Meanwhile, the FBI and Justice Department officials are both investigating. Nascar said just a small number of racing personnel had access to that garage. Nascar's President says if the person responsible is found, they will banned for life from the sport. Investigators are looking at camera footage in that garage, and who could have had access to that area.

And finally, here is a look at what is trending this morning on foxbusiness.com. Ben & Jerry's says it's considering boycotting advertising on Facebook platforms until further action is taken to address racism and social reform. The coronavirus pandemic pushing more than five million shoppers aged 45 and older to buy online. Before the pandemic that age group only made up about five percent of online shopping. And, if and when the market crashes again, if and when, Motley Fool names three stocks you shouldn't have in your portfolio, Aurora Cannabis, Kohl's, and Tesla. Those are your headlines Maria from the newsroom. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: Alright, Cheryl, thank you. Meanwhile, fighting voter fraud is on the front burner now. A bitter debate unfolding over mail-in voting. Advocates for voting by mail argue it will keep voters safe and socially distant amid the pandemic. But critics say it opens the door to ballet tampering. Over the weekend I spoke with US Attorney General William Barr who outlined the threats posed by mail-in ballots.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Well, there's a big discussion right now about mail-in voting.

WILLIAM BARR, UNITED STATES ATTORNEY GENERAL: Yeah.

BARTIROMO: Hillary Clinton said it's fine. It's fair.

BARR: Well it absolutely opens the flood gates to fraud. Those things are delivered in the mailboxes. They can be taken out. There's questions about whether or not it even denies a secret ballot, because a lot of the states have you signing the outside of the envelope, so the purpose, open this envelope, person who opens the envelope will know how people voted. There's no, right now, a foreign country could print up tens of thousands of counterfeit ballots and be very hard for us to detect, which was the right, and which was the wrong ballet. So, I think it can upset and undercut the confidence in the integrity of our elections. If anything, we should tighten them up right now.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: My next guest has filed a lawsuit against California Governor Gavin Newsom to block the state from expanding mail-in voting. Joining me right now is former California Congressman, and now Congressional Candidate himself, Darrell Issa, and Congressman, it's always a pleasure to see you. Thank you so much for being here.

DARRELL ISSA (R-CA) FORMER CONGRESSMAN, CONGRESSIONAL CANDIDATE: Well, thank you Maria. And, you know, with a history in California of excess voters on the rolls, California is particularly shameful in the Governor sending out five million unasked for absentee ballots, or at least he plans to. You know, in Los Angeles alone, when they were sued and challenged on never cleaning up their rolls, they had over one million voters that had to be removed, because of course, they didn't really exist.

BARTIROMO: So, where do we stand right now? Because I know that, you just heard the AG and what he said, that it opens the flood gates of fraud. You know, foreign governments can be printing ballots and we will not even, they could print thousands and thousands of ballots and we will not even know what's the real thing and what's just fake from foreign governments trying to meddle in our election. Where do we stand now on mail-in ballots? On a federal level.

ISSA: Well, I'm afraid that--

BARTIROMO: Going into the election.

ISSA: I'm afraid it's Gavin Newsom and the Democrats that are going to be printing those fake ballots. They're not cleaning up the voter rolls. They intent to send those five million excess, unasked for, many of these people have never voted, they were just registered through motor voter. They intend to send them out, but they're doing worse than that, they've just passed a bill, it's on the Governor's desk that actually allows for voting for 17 days after the election. 30 days before, nearly 30 before the election, you can begin voting, but they're allowing for 17 days afterwards, basically to find out how many votes are needed and go get them.

BARTIROMO: Unbelievable. That is unbelievable. So, can the administration do anything about this?

ISSA: Well, there's a real question about whether or not those 17 days will, in fact, create an invalidity. Prior to this time, you had to be postmarked by election day. You could be received afterwards, but you had to have an outside government agency. But with voter harvesting in California, basically, union thugs will go and get these things, maybe for weeks after the election, and questionably where they get them from, because they're going to be mailed to dorm rooms where the students aren't there.

BARTIROMO: Yeah.

ISSA: There's going to be several million ballots just sitting around waiting to be filled out.

BARTIROMO: That's unbelievable. We'll keep watching. This is such an important subject going into the election. But I want to turn to the other election meddling that we're talking about this morning. And that is the Russia probe. During my interview with AG Barr, I asked him about accountability for elected officials. You were there as an oversight chairman. Listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Adam Schiff is an elected official, the Chairman of the Intel Committee. When these guys speak, you stop and listen. Adam Schiff said multiple times that there was collusion in plain sight. Is it no accountability for an elected official, someone that the public obviously trusts, just by their resume, to say one thing in a closed door situation when your under oath, like so many in the Obama administration said, we have no evidence of collusion. But then they went out on television, and they said the complete opposite. They said, collusion is in plain sight. That's a quote from Adam Schiff.

BARR: Well, as far as public comments like these people have been making in press conference and on television and so forth, yeah, the accountability is really elections for Schiff. You know, that's why we have elections. If the people of his district want him to continue to behave as he has, then they can send him back to office. It is infuriating and it's the same phenomenon I discussed with the media, which is the media mislead the American people grossly over a long period of time with exaggerated claims and misinformation. And they haven't been held accountable and the same for a lot of these talking heads.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

ISSA: Well, there's abso--

BARTIROMO: What about that, Congressman?

ISSA: You know, unfortunately we don't hold people who lie under oath in front of Congress accountable and, to be honest, Adam, who came into Congress, we came in together in 2001, his history was that he was for law and order, and the rule of law, and not impeaching people without a good reason. He's done a 180 and his willingness to flat lie and then stand by that lie even when its proven to be wrong is very disappointing. He is, by the way, in a very safe Democratic seat, and perhaps that's the reason that he can be Nancy Pelosi's right arm on these kinds of, in this case, part of an attempted coup of the President.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, shouldn't it be that there's accountability here for three years he said there was collusion in plain sight. He mislead the American people. We know now there was no collusion after spending $40 millions dollars plus on the Mueller report. After three years of the country being in hysteria over this. Where's the accountability? Is anybody going to ask him where's the plain sight?

ISSA: Well there's no question at all, if you're an independent voter in his district you've got to be angry as can be that you've been misled. And so even if you would tend to vote for a Democrat, it's a great time to vote for his opponent and send a strong message that there is a point at which politicians have to be held accountable. It's one thing to say one thing and do another. It's another thing to outright lie about classified information that the American people will never see in most cases, and as a result, mislead them in to believing and losing confidence in their government. This is shameful. He should apologize. He certainly should be defeated in the ballot box, but I'll tell you, it's going to take a lot of independent voters in his district to do it. And I hope they will.

BARTIROMO: Alright, Darrell Issa, great to talk with you this morning. Thank you, sir. We will keep watching all of these developments, particularly that mail-in voting situation.

ISSA: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Coming up, keeping Americans employed. One company doing its part during the COVID-19 pandemic, even expanding. Taking on workers. Then this, T-Rex back on top. Jurassic Park among the classic blockbusters dominating the box office. How much their pulling, coming up right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Bringing America together by keeping American's employed. IT service management company Insight Global, not laying off a single employee during the pandemic, while creating new jobs as part of its response. Joining me right now is Insight Global CEO Bert Bean. Bert, it's great to have you. Thank you so much for joining us.

BERT BEAN, CEO, INSIGHT GLOBAL: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: I want to get into IT spending, and what you're seeing, but first, how were you able to do this?

BEAN: Well, you know, it's, we value our culture tremendously here and we believe that culture drives engagement, and then engagement drives better business results. And so, we just really tried to stick to our guns to not do any layoffs, and to not do any furloughs and by doing so we're able to keep the trust of our people, which allows us to continue to produce strong results.

BARTIROMO: So, I've got to ask you about the CapEx cycle and where you see it right now in terms of companies investing in IT, etc. I'm looking at a Cornerstone Macro report, Nancy Lazar, who's a frequent guest here, says the pieces are falling into place for a renewed CapEx cycle lead by technology. US onshoring is picking up, the COVID-19 economy demands more investment to adapt, from retailers to banks to manufacturers. What are you seeing in that regard?

BEAN: Well, I tell you what, April and May were certainly dark. Those were low, but we are seeing green shoots. We are starting to see more new openings come every single week in our company. And we are starting to see a lot more spend out there, if you go look for it, and that's been one of the things that we've been driving internally, is trying to find ways to even reinvent ourselves a little bit to go find more spend wherever that may be. And one of the things that we did during this pandemic was we actually launched an insight global healthcare staffing division. And just since March 12th we've actually been able to put 3,000 healthcare workers back to work. So, you know, this business is certainly starting to come back. I wouldn't say it's rolling back in, but we are optimists about the signs that we're seeing in the broader economy.

BARTIROMO: Yeah, I'm glad you mentioned the campaign, Be the Light, I want to hear more about it, but Lazar writes that the second quarter real CapEx likely plunge 30 percent, that's the second quarter, these those months that you're referring to that were really bad. But she says the new information is it will probably rebound 10 percent in the third quarter, followed by a sustained expansion in 2021. She's looking at eight percent growth for next year, so CapEx up in the third quarter and up in 2021. Do you believe that to be true?

BEAN: We do believe that to be true. You know, it was a great economy before this, and look, I mean, things like IT are mission critical departments and they, people still to protect their data. People still need to run their businesses, and while this has not been fun three months and while I think we're not quite out of the woods yet, we refer to this time as the long middle that we think we're still in. We do think the Q3 will be strong. Q4 will be stronger and we're very optimistic about 2021.

BARTIROMO: Alright, we will leave it there. Bert, it's great to talk with you this morning. Thanks very much.

BEAN: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Thanks for that campaign, Be the Light. Bert Bean joining us there. Quick break, and then ahead is back to Jurassic Park.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The most phenomenal discovery of our time. How'd you do this? Becomes the greatest adventure of all time.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Oh yeah. The summer classic roars back into theaters. What's behind the comeback? Right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Breaking news this morning, Reuters is reporting that Sanofi is expecting to get approval for its potential coronavirus vaccine that it is developing with GlaxoSmithKline by the first half of next year. Now in April, the company said the vaccine would be available in the second half of 2021, so this is certainly more promising news there from Sanofi this morning.

Time for the morning buzz, first up, not without my pickup truck. A new study from Ford shows American truck drivers are willing to give up some of life's luxuries before they give up their pickups. They include streaming services, alcohol, coffee, their phones, meat, even intimacy. Dagen, do you have pickup truck? I need some confirmation on all of this, because I'm not buying all of this. You're going to give all this stuff up for the pickup. What do you think?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FOX BUSINESS CONTRIBUTOR: I'm not either, and I got my driver's license in a Ford F-150 and drove a full sized Bronco which is essentially a pickup truck for years and years and years. If you, 82 percent of the truck owners in this survey would rather give up streaming services, but the intimacy, the sex part, that fell to 38 percent of respondents, said they would give us sex to keep they're truck. I suspect its much lower than that. A lot of people would rather hang onto the intimacy and drive a lawnmower.

BARTIROMO: I'd say. Next up, devouring some classic films, Director Stephen Spielberg's iconic Jurassic Park hitting it big again. This time at Drive In theaters. The film pulling in $517,000 dollars in one weekend at more than 230 nationwide locations. Another Spielberg hit, Jaws, earned $516,000 over a weekend. Jon, you've seen both.

JON HILSENRATH, SENIOR WRITER, THE WALL STREET JOURNAL: I sure have, and you know, at drive in theatres watching Jaws, I think I've got to go find my mom's old Ford Country Squire station wagon with no seat belts and back that up into a drive in theater watch in from that.

BARTIROMO: I sort of like this whole drive in idea. I've never been to a drive in, I would like to check it out. Alright, finally this.

HILSENRATH: I spent my summers in drive in theaters.

BARTIROMO: The happiest place on earth is still on pause, unfortunately, as Disneyland hopes to reopen on July 9th. The Coalition of Resort Labor Unions pushing back on the plan. Many workers say they still do no feel there's enough time to make employees and guests feel safe in the park. Mattie, would you go?

MATTIE DUPPLER, SENIOR FELLOW, THE NATIONAL TAXPAYERS UNION: Well, Maria, this is the challenge with the lack of leadership at the state level with the reopening in the state. There needs to be clear guidance, so consumers and workers feel protected and safe. Congress needs to step in here too with the next round of coronavirus relief or support, but really clarifying what it is that the rules are going to be in these states as they reopen. Particularly with large arenas, like something like Disneyland.

BARTIROMO: Alright, we will take a break. President Trump just Tweeting on prosecuting people vandalizing monuments. Here's what the President just wrote. He writes this, I have authorized the Federal Government to arrest anyone who vandalizes or destroys any monument, statue or other such Federal property in the United States with up to 10 years in prison per the Veterans and Memorial Preservation Act, or such other laws that may be pertinent. This action is taking effective immediately but may also be used retroactively for destruction of vandalism already caused. There will be no exceptions. Do you think this is going to stop the vandalism of our monuments across the country? Ten years in prison. We're going to talk about it. More Mornings with Maria when we come right back. Stay with us.

Aug 12, 2020( The American Prospect Blogs: http://prospect.org/blogs Delivered by Newstex) ; First Response Amid the Trump and circumstance and everyone's take on Kamala Harris, we have lost sight of an economic depression now playing out in slow motion. As of this moment, no unemployed person in America is getting anything above their state's share in weekly checks. After governors pushed back strongly[1] on Trump's executive measure, which would have had them pony up 25 percent of a $400 unemployment boost (California[2], Kentucky[3], New Jersey[4], and really everybody; this map[5] lists the states that have spoken publicly on it), the White House acknowledged that the state share will not be required[6], and unemployed workers will just get $300. This appears to be illegal under the statutory authority they're using to do this unilaterally, which requires a 25 percent match. But since when has the law been relevant?

When anyone will get even that $300 is an open question, as it will take significant reprogramming of state unemployment systems. Meanwhile, I haven't heard a single company say they'll actually stop withholding payroll taxes to give workers a temporary, ephemeral 6.2 percent pay boost. So for the foreseeable future, the economic impact of the Trump unilateral actions is nothing.There is increasingly no hope of actual talks to create a Congressional package. Claims from both sides[7] that they're 'open[8]' to talks haven't led any to happen, the chief of staff and chief enforcer[9] in deal negotiations Mark Meadows has left town for a week, and the House is out of town[10] until September 14. Every expectation is that nothing will happen[11] until at least then, and I think it could be longer. You have Republicans who've found their inner deficit hawk cheerleading failure[12], and in general there's nothing compelling bringing them to the table, after the corporate bailout was set in motion in March.Read all of our Unsanitized reports[13]In the meantime, we can expect the economy to deteriorate, potentially rapidly. More rent payments are getting put on credit cards[14], a sign of financial stress. People are liquidating 401(k) plans[15] for ready cash. Food pantries are seeing record demand[16]. The evictions have begun[17]. People are saving in expectation of an extended recession, creating the vicious cycle that leads to recession-induced job loss, not just pandemic-related layoffs. State and local budget crunches[18] (5.6 percent annualized spending cuts last quarter, with more to come) are just going to compound this pain, and the federal government has pulled out all the supports for the economy. This situation is dire.What can be done about it? How can depression be prevented through a fiscal deal?The answer, in my estimation, lies in suing every corporation in sight.There are only a couple ways to get Republicans, who have little interest in further relief on its own, to the table to make a deal. One would be a collapse of the stock market. But it's approaching an all-time high[19], and whatever stumble came at the end of yesterday's session after fears of an impasse on fiscal relief have subsided by today, as stocks are up[20]. As long as the Fed keeps vowing to inflate assets, and as long as the companies dominating the Dow—Big Tech, essentially—keep expanding their market position, there's little reason for investors to worry. Your donation keeps this site free and open for all to read. Give what you can...SUPPORT THE PROSPECT[21]Even if the market does deteriorate as the reality of the next depression hits, by that time we'll be in the undertow of an economic collapse. This is not what you want to wait for to get Republicans to think seriously about a fiscal response. So hoping stocks go under is not a realistic option.The only other thing that has roused Republicans in recent weeks is this idea that corporations will be endlessly sued by workers and customers over contracting COVID-19, and that we need a mass liability release to protect them. The problem is that there is no flood of lawsuits[22] at the moment, relieving the pressure for this. But let's do a thought experiment here. What if every trial lawyer in America started streaming into courts with wrongful death and injury lawsuits? What if every corporation in America suddenly had to deal with liability on a mass scale? What if the suits sought to make CEOs personally liable for this activity?Maybe the courts are so in hock to corporate interests that this wouldn't cause much concern either. But I'd gather that more lobbyists would be in the ear of Republicans to get to bargaining if there were thousands of lawsuits hanging over them, compared to now, when almost no suits have been filed.Sure, what would result would be distasteful: Republicans would eagerly seek immunity for corporations' role in the deaths of thousands of people. But this depression will also kill thousands of people. And what's standing in the way of that right now is a lack of interest on the part of Republicans to do anything about it. The immunity can be written far more narrowly than Mitch McConnell's opening bid, which pretty much would have put medical malpractice cases on ice for five years. But at least if immunity were on the table, there might actually be a negotiation.This modest proposal reverses the terrible mistake Democrats made in not getting long-lasting relief the last time there was something Republicans wanted. That's going to come at a high cost.Unfortunately, liberals aren't the well-organized machine of conservative fever dreams. There is no Bat-signal to the trial lawyers to start ramping up cases. But that's what I think it'll take for there to be any interest in an actual bargain. It's sad, of course. But it's also necessary. Odds and Sods Some Monopolized[23] news: I was on BNN Bloomberg (the Canadian version of the business network) discussing the book. Watch here[24]. I also was on the LitHub podcast with Andrew Keen for a long discussion. Listen here[25].WHYY's Radio Times had me on yesterday to discuss the Big Tech hearings. Listen here[26].And at about 8:30 of this 'Closer Look' segment on Late Night with Seth Meyers, you can see a clip from me talking about the post office. Watch here[27].I'm deliberately not linking to a New York Times story that blatantly rips off The Capitol Forum and us, in telling the story about the Postal Service seeking[28] to force higher postage rates[29] from states to deliver mail-in ballots[30] without crediting the originators (see the links) who told the story. This is depressingly common and an extension of many of the themes in Monopolized, with big incumbents muscling out competition by just copying them. The Times' building facilities department is probably bigger that our staff and the Capitol Forum's combined. They have every ability to get their own stories. And if they don't, one line of credit saying where it originated from is literally the least they can do. It's shameful and designed to undermine media diversity, as in 'nobody should exist but the New York Times.' So get your Times coverage elsewhere from now on. Your donation keeps this site free and open for all to read. Give what you can...SUPPORT THE PROSPECT[31]This piece from Katya Schwenk[32] on the history of one privately managed ICE facility where almost 90 percent of the detainees have contracted coronavirus is first-rate. And we have Shera Avi-Yonah, one of our interns, on the struggles of voter registration drives[33] during the pandemic.You can read all of our coronavirus coverage at prospect.org/coronavirus[34]. urn:contentItem:60JX-0DV1-F03R-N02B-00000-00Unsanitized: More Evidence That the Postal Service Means to Make Voting Harder2020-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:17ZLexisNexisUnsanitized: More Evidence That the Postal Service Means to Make Voting HarderDavid Dayen

Aug 11, 2020( The American Prospect Blogs: http://prospect.org/blogs Delivered by Newstex) ;; First Response There was some pushback on the claim made in reporting by the Capitol Forum that the U.S. Postal Service wants to increase the rates[1] at which states would pay to mail ballots to voters from the 20-cent marketing mail rate to the 55-cent first class rate. The USPS put out a denial and everything, calling it a 'baseless assertion without merit, and frivolous.' But it was carefully worded, calling only the idea that the postal service would raise rates in order to restrict voting by mail meritless, and that 'if public policy makers choose to utilize the mail as part of their election system' the agency would stand ready.A letter unearthed yesterday[2] reveals how the USPS might be influencing that decision. This letter, sent to Kim Wyman, Secretary of State of the vote-by-mail state of Washington, addressed how 'certain deadlines concerning mail-in ballots may be incongruous with the Postal Service's delivery standards.'

Specifically, it notes that states can use either marketing mail or first-class mail to get their ballots to voters, but that first-class mail would get them there significantly faster.'The Postal Service recommends that election officials use First Class Mail to transmit blank ballots and allow 1 week for delivery to voters,' the letter reads. 'Using Marketing Mail will result in slower delivery times and will increase the risk that voters will not receive their ballots in time to return them by mail.'Note that a previous letter to election officials, referenced in this one, went out May 29, before Trump donor Louis DeJoy was installed as Postmaster General, and then this one, dated July 31, went out after he was in place.Read all of our Unsanitized reports[3]There is definitely a way to read this letter as the Postal Service helpfully reminding election officials of key dates and timelines for delivery, so they can get ballots printed and out to voters in a reasonable timeframe. Indeed, the rest of the letter is specific to Washington, states that ballots are usually mailed out with enough advance time, and expresses concern mainly for voters who update their voter registration after the mailing date. States may be setting unrealistic goals with their own systems on what can be done with mail-in voting.But all that would divorce this letter from the context of prior reporting that the Postal Service really wants states to pay the increased rate, and that states and cities are increasingly cash-strapped. It would also divorce it from the reality that mail is slowing down[4] and backlogs are seen everywhere. (DeJoy has denied the slowdowns[5], and any ulterior motive about the election.)It's hard to believe that this is about money. Let's say that every single registered voter in the United States—153 million[6] as of 2018—gets a ballot mailed to them. (They won't, but for the sake of argument let's say that.) The net increase from 20 cents to 55 cents is a total of $53.55 million. That level 'is not going to help the postal service appreciably,' said Rick Hasen, election law professor at UC-Irvine; it's a tiny portion of their overall revenue. Your donation keeps this site free and open for all to read. Give what you can...SUPPORT THE PROSPECT[7]It may create enough of an excuse, however, to have local election officials decide not to mail ballots at all, citing the increased cost. That appears to be the play here, to put states and cities in the position to create their own hurdles for voters.Marc Elias, the Democrats' top election lawyer, called the letter[8] 'an early warning that USPS has abdicated its responsibility to facilitate a free and fair election.' He said that states now face a 'logistical and financial crisis' in preventing mass disenfranchisement, and cited examples from previous primary elections of thousands of ballots being left uncounted.Meanwhile, the Capitol Forum has a follow-up, revealing documents where career staff warn that raising the price of ballot delivery would violate the National Voter Registration Act or the Voting Rights Act. The documents also show that USPS top brass saw this as an opportunity to raise revenue (as noted above, this isn't that true, so it's probably a fig leaf for regulatory purposes) and that the initiative was designated a 'high priority' by leadership.Raising the ballot cost would be almost impossible to do statutorily at this point, given that it would require regulatory action and need to survive a lawsuit. But the letter shows an alternative route: darkly warn that ballots won't get to voters in time unless states pay more. And if states use that to change their systems and place burdens on voters to get a ballot, that's just the way it goes. Odds and Sods Here are my segments from Democracy Now[9] yesterday. The first, with American Postal Workers Union president Mark Dimondstein, discusses the Postal Service[10]. The second covers Trump's executive measures on coronavirus relief[11].I was on The Ring of Fire with Sam Seder[12] talking about the Big Tech hearings. Listen here[13].I was on WHYY's Radio Times[14] this morning discussing the tech industry. Listen here[15].We have a lot of coronavirus coverage at the Prospect. Blaise Malley[16] on the risk to the census; Gayle Greene[17] with an excellent feature on how education technology firms are cashing in on the crisis; Connor Goodwin[18] on Nebraska meatpacking workers; and Bob Kuttner[19] on the testing debacle.You can read all of our coronavirus coverage at prospect.org/coronavirus[20]. And email me[21] with tips, comments, and perspectives. Days Without a Bailout Oversight Chair 138[22]. Today I Learned Your donation keeps this site free and open for all to read. urn:contentItem:5YPT-60C1-F03R-N2B9-00000-00Unshocking Report: Trump Admin Is Historically Terrible At Reining In Destructive Monopolies2020-04-20T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:17ZLexisNexisUnshocking Report: Trump Admin Is Historically Terrible At Reining In Destructive MonopoliesKarl Bode

Apr 20, 2020( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) You need only look at its treatment of the telecom industry to understand that the Trump administration doesn't give a flying damn about U.S. monopolies (or the impact those monopolies have on consumers, prices, innovation, or the market). Despite being one of the least competitive (and least popular) industries in America, the administration has taken a hatchet to telecom consumer protections, often using bogus data[1] and fraud[2] to do it. Massive, competition and job-eroding mergers are rubber stamped before the administration even sees the data[3]. Any pretense at meaningful oversight is theater. A new report by the American Antitrust Institute[4] suggests that despite the administration's rhetoric around "big tech," its apathy to monopolies is fairly uniform. Experts have noted for a decade than US antitrust enforcement has grown toothless and frail[5], and our definitions of monopoly power need updating in the Amazon era[6]. Antitrust enforcement had already waned under the Obama administration, getting severely worse once Trump came to power:"Despite its anti-corporate concentration rhetoric on the campaign trail, key metrics of cartel and merger enforcement have declined since the Trump administration took over.

And in 2017 and 2018, the DOJ did not open one monopolization investigation, the longest span of inattention to dominant firms in the last 50 years."That's not particularly surprising for those who watched the head of the Trump DOJ antitrust division, Makan Delrahim, not only ignore the input of his staff[7] and approve T-Mobile's competition eroding $26 billion merger with Sprint, but personally helped usher the deal through the process[8] via his personal phone and email accounts. The report notes that cartel investigations, fines, and the amount of fines levied are down overall as well, with the number of corporations fined by the Trump agencies in 2017 and 2018 falling by about 45% compared to the Obama administration. This sort of corruption isn't new, and it's certainly bipartisan. Trump's just exponentially worse at disguising feckless obedience to profit and corporate power as a more elaborate ethos. For years, America routinely embraced mindless "deregulation" of broken markets like telecom under the belief that antitrust enforcement would come in and maintain some semblance of proper balance. That is, again unsurprisingly, proving to be total fantasy in practice:"As markets have changed over time, deregulation garnered broad support through bipartisan efforts intended to remove regulatory barriers that were thought to impede competition more than their benefits could justify. This was based, however, on the assumption that lost government oversight would become unnecessary due to active antitrust enforcement. Conservative administrations have often deregulated without concern for whether antitrust enforcement or competition policy would effectively fill the gap."When the administration does act, it often acts for the wrong reasons, as seen with the short-lived "antitrust investigation[9]" into the auto industry for adhering to pollution standards. Or the administration's lawsuit to stop the AT&TTime Warner deal, which had less to do with protecting markets and consumers, and more to do with making Rupert Murdoch happy[10] and getting revenge on CNN for critical coverage[11] of his bumbling and corrupt administration. Throughout all of this, somehow, many policy folks and tech reporters still somehow take Trump's rhetoric about reining in "big tech" monopolies seriously. The DOJ's announcement of "investigations" into everyone from Google to Apple are treated with deadpan seriousness by a press and policy ecosystem that doesn't seem to learn from experience. Some Economists advise we perhaps should stop doing that, since there's zero indication the administration takes Section 2 of the Sherman Act seriously, and there's very little indication any of these investigations will result in substantive action: Tech reporters breathlessly reporting on the DOJ's imminent case against the tech platforms need to take a chill pill. Ain't gonna happen under this administration. They don't believe in section 2. pic.twitter.com/P3O9m3O1WQ[12] — Hal Singer (@HalSinger) April 14, 2020[13]More often than not, such investigations are being used more for leverage on other issues (see: Barr's war on encryption, or more positive coverage and ranking). Because in reality, Trump cares about three things: attention, power, and personal enrichment. It's not clear how much more idiotic theater we need to witness before policy experts and tech reporters understand that, and stop treating egomania, grift, and corruption as "very serious urn:contentItem:5XWN-GJ31-F06X-W3SB-00000-00UNSTOPPABLE;Little can keep Google from entering wealth management. But advisors still have weapons at their disposal. They just need to use them.2020-01-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:17ZLexisNexisSPECIAL REPORT: TECH GIANTS IN WEALTH MANAGEMENTPg. 14UNSTOPPABLELittle can keep Google from entering wealth management. But advisors still have weapons at their disposal. They just need to use them.Sean Allocca

Advisor Tom Balcom doesn't feel threatened by his clients' use of budgeting or savings apps. He is unconcerned about Google's announcement that it may offer a consumer checking account. But he is a little nervous about how comfortable clients have become with an array of digital financial tools, and what that might mean for his livelihood.

"I would not be shocked if Google offers more planning," says Balcom, the founder of 1650 Wealth Management, an RIA in Lauderdale-by-the Sea, Florida.

For many advisors, though, it's not if, but when.

Even now, technology allows firms to seamlessly partner with broker-dealers or independent advisors to offer managed investment accounts, lending products, checking accounts and retirement vehicles. At the same time, other barriers between traditional financial services and wealth management are breaking down.

Apple, for instance, launched its credit card in March. In November, Google said it would look to partner with Citigroup to offer checking accounts sometime this year. While the firms may use the accounts to collect client data and peek more deeply into customers' behavior, they are also seen as taking big steps toward the traditional purview of wealth management.

"It's obvious from where I sit that big tech will want to make the jump," says Jud Mackrill, chief marketing officer at Carson Group. "A managed account solution is going to come along with one of these product launches."

These latest offerings are an unwelcome reminder of an ever-present question on the minds of wealth managers: Will the FAANG companies - Facebook, Amazon, Apple, Netflix and Google - as well as other big tech companies make a land grab of services historically provided by financial services? If so, at what cost to traditional RIAs?

"Potentially, if Google got cleared to conduct a brokerage business, they could move in any direction they want," says Greg O'Gara, a senior research analyst at Aite Group.

"Essentially, nothing is going to stop the democratization of investing through technology, and once one of these [tech companies] makes an imprint on the broker-dealer landscape, the growth prospects are very, very good," he adds.

Google's entry into finance can be traced, in part, to recent efforts by fintechs to evolve beyond investing and advice. And, just as those partnerships have rapidly grown, there is little to prevent the search engine giant from teaming up with a broker to launch a wealth management pilot.

"We're exploring how we can partner with banks and credit unions in the U.S. to offer smart checking accounts through Google Pay," says Google spokesman Craig Ewer. In the United States, more than 2,000 banks already offer card transactions via Google Pay, Ewer says.

Last year, a host of digital wealth managers served up a buffet of new financial services options including banking and lending.

Betterment and many of its competitors added cash products with annual percentage yields sometimes as much as 2% more than traditional accounts at incumbent banks. (The yields depend heavily on prevailing interest rates.

Wealthfront advertised its account as the highest-yielding in the market when it announced in early 2019, and says that it attracted $1 billion in assets as a result.

The most successful may be from micro-savings app Acorns, which was one of the first to tack on additional services and now boasts checking, debit cards and retirement savings vehicles with 6.2 million accounts and $1.7 billion in AUM, according to the firm. Its retirement product, Acorns Later, built up 170,000 accounts in its first two months, according to Acorns CEO Noah Kerner.

The business strategy of partnering with financial institutions has essentially been mapped by smaller fintechs and has proved successful. Google is now emulating that model to launch its checking account slated to pilot this year. The question may now become not whether tech giants will enter wealth management - but what can possibly stop them?

Carson Wealth Management became one of the first big advisory firms to offer checking accounts to its clients last May.

Through its partnership with the digital banking provider Galileo, Carson's RIA clients have access to a Mastercard-branded debit card, online bill paying, direct deposit options and the ability to use tens of thousands of ATMs, according to the firm.

"We view Amazon as the competition," Ron Carson, CEO of Carson Group, told Financial Planning after Apple announced its credit card launch in March. "Whenever they decide to get directly into our business, we have to be prepared. They haven't yet because there is just so much low-hanging fruit. But they are coming."

Too big to succeed?

Ominously for independents, a majority of investors who are considering switching financial services providers said they would think about banking with tech companies such as Facebook, Google or Amazon if they could, according to a recent survey by MX, a digital banking technology provider.

Almost 60% of the survey respondents said they would consider depositing a paycheck with a major technology company.

"Cash is a very easy commodity to generate income on, and once you attract clients, you can cross-sell anything," O'Gara says.

"There really is not much that would stop them from building out a broader investment platform. With the right regulatory oversight, nothing is stopping them," he adds.

It's not a foregone conclusion, however. Google had a similar product, Google Compare, that compared different financial products for consumers, which potentially could have shifted into robo advice. It was shuttered in 2016. "Google has a bit of attention deficit" disorder, Mackrill says. "They'll try something new and have no problem killing it."

The fintech partnerships have one important advantage: the ability to leapfrog regulatory hurdles. Many RIAs cite regulation as a top barrier preventing FAANGs from entering wealth management.

"The team at Google Pay has been working for years to help make money simple and accessible for our users, in close partnership with banks, credit unions, and the existing regulatory and financial systems," the Google spokesman says. "We believe our partners' regulatory and financial know-how is a great complement to our experience in building helpful tools and technology for our users."

What about robos?

What's stopping Google from offering an off-the-shelf retirement product? The answer is, not much.

"If I were a robo advisor, I would certainly be worried," says 1650 Wealth Management's Balcom. "Amazon is probably not far behind."

However, the robo advice industry is also a crowded soup of new entrants, and the initial results haven't been as promising as some had hoped.

Major competitors like Schwab and Vanguard have their own megalithic robo platforms, and many of the FAANG companies may hesitate to enter a highly regulated market with entrenched competitors, says Eric Walters, founder of SilverCrest Wealth Planning, an RIA located in Greenwood Village, Colorado.

Another reason that a move by Google into wealth management may not be imminent is the current economics of the digital financial advice space, which are tough, given high customer acquisition costs and increased pricing pressure as the industry shifts to zero commissions in trading.

"They would rather leverage their ubiquity, control of consumer data and iconic cultural status to facilitate the flow of money - including via partners like Citigroup - to the extent they become irreplaceable components of the financial services ecosystem," says Will Trout, a senior analyst at Celent.

Even if advisors don't expect to face direct competition for clients from big technology firms, one could well offer a new platform, like a wealth management integration, that RIAs might then adopt, says Linda Erickson, founder of Erickson Advisors, an RIA in Greensboro, North Carolina.

"I can't see [big tech firms] replacing my money management skills," Erickson says. "Where money management is a commodity - not personalized - maybe they will develop a better approach than robo advisors. I doubt client relationships will be entirely replaced by artificial intelligence."

Still, automated advice continues to defy the industry's initial growth expectations. Assets under robos are expected to grow to over $1.26 trillion by 2023, according to a study by Aite Group.

In fact, robo advice was listed as one of the top technologies that would change wealth management in the course of the next three years, according to Financial Planning's latest annual Tech Survey. Robos beat out other high-profile technologies like artificial intelligence and advanced risk profiling.

Resistance is unwise

Whether or not Google ends up getting into the wealth management game, there are tangible steps RIAs can take to mitigate the potential risks.

The first is to find additional value beyond what a FAANG robo advisor would provide clients.

"At the end of the day, advisors shouldn't be focused on the tech companies coming in," Mackrill says. "They should be focused on what they can actually control."

Advisors will need to provide value to their clients through comprehensive financial planning or a unique investment strategy that is not available through automated platforms, Mackrill says.

Some good places to start include adding tax services, financial planning or estate planning.

Ultimately, the human element will be the advisor's secret weapon.

"The future of advice looks a lot more like therapy than anything else," Mackrill says.

RIAs will have to open their eyes to the potential risks from tech disruptors, because ultimately technological transformation will happen, he says. It might not be the FAANGs that come into the advice marketplace, but they represent a larger ideology. Change is coming - and RIAs have traditionally been resistant to change.

"It's certainly a growing problem," Mackrill says. "And looming larger by the day."

Sean Allocca is an associate editor of Financial Planning. Follow him on Twitter at @sjallocca.

urn:contentItem:5T4Y-YX71-DY93-M0M0-00000-00UN urges Facebook to 'proactively' fight hate speech2018-08-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:17ZLexisNexisUN urges Facebook to 'proactively' fight hate speechGeneva, Aug 29 2018

The UN human rights chief urged Facebook Wednesday to more proactively address hate speech but warned against excessive regulation, after US President Donald Trump accused tech giants' platforms of bias against him.

Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein's appeal follows a decision by Facebook this week to ban Myanmar's army chief and other top military brass named in a UN probe linking them to a possible "genocide" against Rohingya Muslims.

The social media network is the prime source of news and information for many in the country, but has also been a platform for the army and Buddhist hardliners to spread hate speech against the Rohingya and other minorities.

The site aired support for the military's bloody "clearance operations" last year that forced some 700,000 Rohingya over the border into Bangladesh.

"We felt early on very uncomfortable with what we were seeing in Myanmar, (but) in the early meetings that we had with Facebook, I didn't think they were taking it seriously," said Zeid, who is due to step down from his post as UN High Commissioner for Human Rights at the end of the week.

"Hopefully they've now awoken," he told reporters in Geneva, warning that there could easily be other cases "where Facebook is the dominant medium in a country where you see a deterioration of human rights conditions and then their role would be brought into question."

He cautioned that the company should be "careful", since it risked being subpoenaed in possible future trials "of those accused of the worst crimes."

- 'Accessory' -

"We've seen from the jurisprudence of the past that if you've enabled, you've abetted, you've been an accessory," Zeid said, stressing that while he was not accusing Facebook of that, "they have to be sure that they know where they are and what side of the law they are on."

The Jordanian national, who is set to be succeeded by former Chilean president Michelle Bachelet, urged Facebook to not wait until a full-blown crisis erupts to act against hate speech.

"They should be thinking proactively about what steps they will take to mitigate that," he said.

Zeid meanwhile warned of going too far in the opposite direction, cautioning that "there is also another danger (of being) overregulated."

He pointed to recent comments by the US president, who has accused big tech firms like Facebook, Google and Twitter of bias against him, slamming what he called "rigged" internet search results.

Trump offered no details on what if any actions he might take, but a top White House aide suggested the administration may look at some type of regulation in response to the president's complaints.

Zeid insisted that instead of more government regulations, the platforms' actions must "be regulated by (international) human rights law."

- 'Dangerous' -

The comments did not mark the first time the UN rights chief has criticised Trump.

He has repeatedly warned that the US president's relentless attacks on the media are "dangerous".

On Wednesday, Zeid said Trump's recent statements "have been very worrisome to me," reiterating his warning that the president's words could trigger violence against journalists.

"All of us would be horrified, but perhaps not shocked if we heard of a journalist that was attacked and severely beaten for example at one of the rallies," he said, stressing that if that happens "the president would bear some responsibility."

"As the campaigning seasons heat up, whether it be for the midterm elections or the presidential elections to come, the conduct of the president should be under very careful scrutiny by the international community and by this office," Zeid said.

UN Urges Facebook to 'Proactively' Fight Hate Speech

August 29, 2018 3:08 PM

GENEVA -

The UN human rights chief urged Facebook Wednesday to more proactively address hate speech but warned against excessive regulation, after US President Donald Trump accused tech giants' platforms of bias against him.

Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein's appeal follows a decision by Facebook this week to ban Myanmar's army chief and other top military brass named in a UN probe linking them to a possible "genocide" against Rohingya Muslims.

The social media network is the prime source of news and information for many in the country, but has also been a platform for the army and Buddhist hardliners to spread hate speech against the Rohingya and other minorities.

The site aired support for the military's bloody "clearance operations" last year that forced some 700,000 Rohingya over the border into Bangladesh.

"We felt early on very uncomfortable with what we were seeing in Myanmar, (but) in the early meetings that we had with Facebook, I didn't think they were taking it seriously," said Zeid, who is due to step down from his post as UN High Commissioner for Human Rights at the end of the week.

"Hopefully they've now awoken," he told reporters in Geneva, warning that there could easily be other cases "where Facebook is the dominant medium in a country where you see a deterioration of human rights conditions and then their role would be brought into question."

He cautioned that the company should be "careful," since it risked being subpoenaed in possible future trials "of those accused of the worst crimes."

'Accessory'

"We've seen from the jurisprudence of the past that if you've enabled, you've abetted, you've been an accessory," Zeid said, stressing that while he was not accusing Facebook of that, "they have to be sure that they know where they are and what side of the law they are on."

The Jordanian national, who is set to be succeeded by former Chilean president Michelle Bachelet, urged Facebook to not wait until a full-blown crisis erupts to act against hate speech.

"They should be thinking proactively about what steps they will take to mitigate that," he said.

Zeid meanwhile warned of going too far in the opposite direction, cautioning that "there is also another danger (of being) overregulated."

He pointed to recent comments by the US president, who has accused big tech firms like Facebook, Google and Twitter of bias against him, slamming what he called "rigged" internet search results.

Trump offered no details on what if any actions he might take, but a top White House aide suggested the administration may look at some type of regulation in response to the president's complaints.

Zeid insisted that instead of more government regulations, the platforms' actions must "be regulated by (international) human rights law."

'Dangerous'

The comments did not mark the first time the UN rights chief has criticized Trump.

He has repeatedly warned that the US president's relentless attacks on the media are "dangerous."

On Wednesday, Zeid said Trump's recent statements "have been very worrisome to me," reiterating his warning that the president's words could trigger violence against journalists.

"All of us would be horrified, but perhaps not shocked if we heard of a journalist that was attacked and severely beaten for example at one of the rallies," he said, stressing that if that happens "the president would bear some responsibility."

"As the campaigning seasons heat up, whether it be for the midterm elections or the presidential elections to come, the conduct of the president should be under very careful scrutiny by the international community and by this office," Zeid said.
