urn:contentItem:5TY6-H121-DY19-C02M-00000-00'Unworkable, unnecessary, unprecedented': Facebook hits back at ACCC2018-12-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:17ZLexisNexis'Unworkable, unnecessary, unprecedented': Facebook hits back at ACCCJohn McDuling

Social media behemoth Facebook has broken its silence to hit back at the Australian competition regulator's tough new proposals.

Social media behemoth Facebook has hit back at the Australian competition regulator's proposal for a new government body to scrutinise its business and algorithms, describing the plan as "unnecessary", "unprecedented" and "unworkable".

Andy O'Connell, a senior policy executive from Facebook's global headquarters in Menlo Park, California, who works closely with its chief executive Mark Zuckerberg, signalled the company was concerned the new measures proposed by Australia could gain global support.

"This idea that we would create a generalised algorithm regulator without a specific set of problems they are trying to fix, to make choices for consumers rather than putting users in control, it is pretty unprecedented," Mr O'Connell, a top policy executive, said in Facebook's first public comments on the issue this week.

"This is unprecedented as far as I am aware. I am not aware of any other country seriously looking at this idea of an algorithm regulator."

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission earlier this week released landmark findings from a year-long inquiry into digital platforms, declaring that Google and Facebook's substantial market power in digital advertising is hurting traditional publishers.

The regulator proposed a number of measures to curb their dominance, including a new government body to monitor their conduct in the advertising market, and to scrutinise how their secretive algorithms distribute traffic to publishers.

It also wants to create a new ombudsman to monitor consumer complaints about the platforms, toughen privacy regulations and make it harder for the tech giants to collect user data without unambiguous consent.

"There is not a lot of clarity in what it would do but ... it seems pretty unworkable," Mr O'Connell said of the proposal for a new regulator.

"At its core [Facebook's] news feed is just a list of pages you have chosen to follow and people who have chosen to be friends with, the news feed is just a process of ordering them.

"These algorithms are personalised feeds based on choices individual people have made, so it is really hard to conceive how a government body can intervene in those choices."

In its report, the ACCC said the algorithmic selection of news is exposing users to risks of "filter bubbles" and unreliable information that could have flow-on effects for democracy.

Facebook has been hit by a series of scandals this year involving its news feed, including admissions the platform was manipulated by Russian troll groups spreading misinformation during the 2016 US elections, and criticism for acting too slowly to prevent hate speech from spreading in Myanmar, where there has been a genocide against the Rohingya people.

Facebook in January made substantial changes to its news feed, to refocus its platform on content posted by individual users rather than professional organisations, including media outlets. The changes led to significant drops in traffic for some publishers.

Mr O'Connell said Facebook has for years provided clear public warnings when it makes changes to the way its news feed works. "The focus on transparency doesn't quite seem necessary," he said.

ACCC chair Rod Sims has said he hopes international regulators, including in the US and Europe, follow his lead on regulating big tech.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp has campaigned globally for an 'Algorithm Review Board' to be established to monitor the tech giants' secretive inner workings. But tech industry figures are sceptical whether a government bureaucracy would be able to handle the massive amounts of data involved.

Mr O'Connell said hundreds of thousands of signals are used to determine whether a post makes it into a Facebook users feed. "It's not particularly meaningful to just throw a bunch of code at somebody," he said.

Facebook has 17 million monthly users in Australia, according to the ACCC inquiry. It has 2.3 billion monthly active users around the word.

"I would say that I am concerned about the prospect of any open ended generalised push for a regulator that doesn't have specific ends or problems that it is seeking to address," Mr O'Connell said. "That is what's most concerning about this."

urn:contentItem:5TY6-H121-DY19-C040-00000-00'Unworkable, unnecessary, unprecedented': Facebook hits back at ACCC2018-12-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:41:17ZLexisNexis'Unworkable, unnecessary, unprecedented': Facebook hits back at ACCCJohn McDuling

Social media behemoth Facebook has broken its silence to hit back at the Australian competition regulator's tough new proposals.

Social media behemoth Facebook has hit back at the Australian competition regulator's proposal for a new government body to scrutinise its business and algorithms, describing the plan as "unnecessary", "unprecedented" and "unworkable".

Andy O'Connell, a senior policy executive from Facebook's global headquarters in Menlo Park, California, who works closely with its chief executive Mark Zuckerberg, signalled the company was concerned the new measures proposed by Australia could gain global support.

"This idea that we would create a generalised algorithm regulator without a specific set of problems they are trying to fix, to make choices for consumers rather than putting users in control, it is pretty unprecedented," Mr O'Connell, a top policy executive, said in Facebook's first public comments on the issue this week.

"This is unprecedented as far as I am aware. I am not aware of any other country seriously looking at this idea of an algorithm regulator."

The Australian Competition and Consumer Commission earlier this week released landmark findings from a year-long inquiry into digital platforms, declaring that Google and Facebook's substantial market power in digital advertising is hurting traditional publishers.

The regulator proposed a number of measures to curb their dominance, including a new government body to monitor their conduct in the advertising market, and to scrutinise how their secretive algorithms distribute traffic to publishers.

It also wants to create a new ombudsman to monitor consumer complaints about the platforms, toughen privacy regulations and make it harder for the tech giants to collect user data without unambiguous consent.

"There is not a lot of clarity in what it would do but ... it seems pretty unworkable," Mr O'Connell said of the proposal for a new regulator.

"At its core [Facebook's] news feed is just a list of pages you have chosen to follow and people who have chosen to be friends with, the news feed is just a process of ordering them.

"These algorithms are personalised feeds based on choices individual people have made, so it is really hard to conceive how a government body can intervene in those choices."

In its report, the ACCC said the algorithmic selection of news is exposing users to risks of "filter bubbles" and unreliable information that could have flow-on effects for democracy.

Facebook has been hit by a series of scandals this year involving its news feed, including admissions the platform was manipulated by Russian troll groups spreading misinformation during the 2016 US elections, and criticism for acting too slowly to prevent hate speech from spreading in Myanmar, where there has been a genocide against the Rohingya people.

Facebook in January made substantial changes to its news feed, to refocus its platform on content posted by individual users rather than professional organisations, including media outlets. The changes led to significant drops in traffic for some publishers.

Mr O'Connell said Facebook has for years provided clear public warnings when it makes changes to the way its news feed works. "The focus on transparency doesn't quite seem necessary," he said.

ACCC chair Rod Sims has said he hopes international regulators, including in the US and Europe, follow his lead on regulating big tech.

Rupert Murdoch's News Corp has campaigned globally for an 'Algorithm Review Board' to be established to monitor the tech giants' secretive inner workings. But tech industry figures are sceptical whether a government bureaucracy would be able to handle the massive amounts of data involved.

Mr O'Connell said hundreds of thousands of signals are used to determine whether a post makes it into a Facebook users feed. "It's not particularly meaningful to just throw a bunch of code at somebody," he said.

Facebook has 17 million monthly users in Australia, according to the ACCC inquiry. It has 2.3 billion monthly active users around the word.

"I would say that I am concerned about the prospect of any open ended generalised push for a regulator that doesn't have specific ends or problems that it is seeking to address," Mr O'Connell said. "That is what's most concerning about this."
